column4: someone knows why i can't upgrade 8.04 to 10.04.3 correctly? ever same error: dbus msg
i think you have to do an intermediate upgrade to 9.x... wouldn't swear to it though
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/LucidUpgrades
evidently you can go straight to 10.04
what went wronggggg?
what state is the machine in now?... booting, bricked...?
cool... I'd go with following the instructions either on the page i linked before or else this one: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/EOLUpgrades
good luck :-)
how can i boot ubuntu 11 in usb flashdrive? from this version, 8.04?
does your machine boot from usb?
nope. its already installed. but i want install now the latest version... directly
more easy, i wondering...
why not just save your home directory (including hidden files), do a fresh install, and replace the home directory?
replace to new version?
does it work?
mmm, seems much risk envolved
yes... pretty much all your configuration settings are in your home directory... copy that into a fresh install, apt-get the packages, and they'll come up with the old settings
but exist an way to do with flash drive? on 8.04?
if i miss something, understand?

i suggest a fresh install so that you can rearrange your hard drive in the process... if you create a partition for "/" and another for "/home", then next time you have to upgrade, you won't have to touch your home directory
if i understand, the problem is that you don't have 10.04 on a disk from which you can install... is that right?
yeah! ever i download using update manager i can't end the installation process...
so i think if i install using a flash drive with 11.04 it will work better than refresh...
i just want get the latest version
because 8.04 is already eol, you can't upgrade using update manager anymore. The clean install is my suggestion... but i would advise setting up your hard drive as described before
because that way your subsequent upgrades will be effortless
so if can't upgrade, why i just format? do you know? seems much more secure to me, because im very distractive and i just was made this process over than three times...
will you lose any important data if you just reformat?
nothing... :)
then that would be my suggestion
much better format, isn't it?
the newer versions of ubuntu are much better in many respects than 8.04 :-)
i know... so, how can i boot this version from a flash drive?
perhaps it doesn't have a way in a eol version
download the latest ubuntu from ubuntu.org and on the download page you will find directions for installation from a usb drive
basically, you just write out the iso file to the usb drive, run a live usb version, and do an install from that
but this version doesn't have startup disk creator
no problem... go here: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/ubuntu/download, download the file, go to the bottom of the page and click on "show me how", and you'll be all set :-)
ok! im downloading...
one more question, this file, .iso, needs to be bootable archive, doesn't it?

take a look here: http://www.ubuntu.com/download/ubuntu/download. They show you in 4 steps how to download, make a bootable usb, run the live usb, and install it to your hard disk. Pix and text show you everything you need to know :-)
then i found, or i not found, something... as i was wrote, this version haven't startup disk creator... so i can't do a bootable disk...
do you have UNetbootin?
not, i guess...
try this: "sudo apt-get install usb-creator-gtk"
i haven't the package
where i get that package?
it should be in your repos... checking
is it just past .iso archive?
info about getting usb-creator: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1635782
ok, wait a minute, plz :)
don't worry, i'm not going anywhere ;-)
permission denied
what permission?
i dont know
what did you type that gave you the message?
sudo cat UBUNTU.iso > /dev/sdANDERSON
do it in three commands: first "sudo -i", then "cat UBUNTU.iso > /dev/sdANDERSON", then "exit"
yes, you have to specify the iso file... start typing it and use the tab key for completion... it'll save you much typing
you probably changed directories when you did the sudo -i... just go to your desktop or wherever the file is and you'll be ok
bro, i tyed
ops, i tried to install
tell me your troubles...
unetbootin
then this appeared: "error: dependency is not satisfiable: python-central"
i'd have gone with the cat suggest by zykotick9... it was simple and effective. You just weren't in the right diectory when you issued the command, that's all
but doesn't works...
try this: "sudo -i" then "cd /the/directory/where/your/iso/is", then "cat thenameoftheiso.iso > /dev/theusbdevice", and finally, "exit"
2gb should be more than enough, why?... did you get an out of disk space error?
yeah
you're getting really, really close :-)... if you empty format the usb drive first and repeat what you just did, you should be all set :-)
how can i format?
mkfs.fat16 /dev/whateverdevicetheusbdriveis
it doesn't work...
what's the error message?
mkfs.fat16 /dev/sdANDERSON -bash: mkfs.fat16: command not found
mkdosfs /dev/whateverdevicetheusbdriveis
still not working... write error: no space left on device...
does your disk manager work?
where it is?
i just have disk usage analyzer
system->disk utility or something like that... not the analyzer
type "palimpsest" in a terminal
not exist...
rm -rf /dev/theusbdrive
okay.
and now?
ls -al /dev/theusbdrive
is it empty?
no directory.... i think it is...
mount /dev/theusbdrive
